title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Oil Company Accountability Act" introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Each individual is treated as having made a $500 payment against the tax for the 2006 taxable year. The Secretary will remit this payment to taxpayers within 30 days of enactment. Individuals with no adjusted gross income or exceeding $120,000 in the preceding taxable year are not eligible for this rebate. The section specifies that certain individuals and entities are not eligible for the Energy Tax Rebate, including those with no adjusted gross income or exceeding $120,000 in the previous taxable year, individuals eligible for a deduction under section 151, estates or trusts, and nonresident alien individuals. A conforming amendment is made to Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code. Section 151 of the Energy Tax Rebate excludes certain individuals and entities, such as those with no adjusted gross income or exceeding $120,000 in the previous taxable year, individuals eligible for a deduction under section 151, estates or trusts, and nonresident alien individuals. A conforming amendment is made to Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, United States Code. The amendments for the Energy Tax Rebate, including the revaluation of LIFO inventories for large integrated oil companies, will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. The Energy Tax Rebate Act mandates integrated oil companies to increase the value of historic LIFO inventories and decrease cost of goods sold for the last taxable year ending in 2005. The Energy Tax Rebate Act requires integrated oil companies to adjust the value of historic LIFO inventories by a layer adjustment amount and decrease their cost of goods sold. If the adjustment exceeds the cost of goods sold, the taxpayer's gross income will increase by the excess amount. The layer adjustment amount is calculated based on the product of the historic LIFO layer. The Energy Tax Rebate Act requires integrated oil companies to adjust historic LIFO inventories by a layer adjustment amount. If the adjustment exceeds the cost of goods sold, the taxpayer's gross income will increase by the excess amount. The layer adjustment amount is calculated based on the product of the historic LIFO layer and $18.75 per barrel of crude oil. The Energy Tax Rebate Act mandates integrated oil companies to adjust historic LIFO inventories by a layer adjustment amount. This adjustment is based on the product of the historic LIFO layer and $18.75 per barrel of crude oil. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined as the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the layer. Any required adjustment under this section is not considered a change in accounting method. The term "barrel-of-oil equivalent" is defined as the number of barrels of crude oil represented by the layer. Any adjustment required by this section is not considered a change in accounting method. No addition to the tax shall be made under section 6655 of the Internal Revenue Code with respect to any underpayment of an installment required to be paid for the taxable year. The term "applicable integrated oil company" is defined for tax purposes as an integrated oil company. No tax addition shall be made for underpayments of estimated tax related to the taxable year. The term "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as an integrated oil company with specific production and revenue criteria. An applicable integrated oil company must have an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil and gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 for its last taxable year ending in 2005. All persons treated as a single employer are considered one entity for this purpose. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES WHO ARE DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax. Large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers will not have amounts paid to foreign countries or possessions of the United States considered as taxes if the country or possession does not impose a generally applicable income tax, or if the amount exceeds a certain limit determined by regulations. If a foreign country or possession does not impose a generally applicable income tax, or if the amount paid by a dual capacity taxpayer exceeds a certain limit determined by regulations, the amounts paid will not be considered as taxes. The generally applicable income tax paid by a dual capacity taxpayer in a foreign country or possession is considered as taxes, as long as it does not exceed a certain limit determined by regulations. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy in a foreign country or possession of the United States. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy in a foreign country or possession of the United States, who receives a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from conducting a trade or business within that country or possession. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to an income tax imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from conducting a trade or business within that country or possession, excluding taxes that do not apply substantially to non-dual capacity taxpayers or citizens. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company meeting specific criteria for any taxable year. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil for a taxable year. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as a company with gross receipts over $1,000,000,000 and daily worldwide oil production of at least 500,000 barrels. The amendments apply to taxes in taxable years after the enactment date, except where they conflict with US treaty obligations.
